posts.name:
Philip Intallura Ph.D
Philip Intallura Ph.D
posts.content:
Steve Jobs‚Äô 7 Radical Innovation Principles.

Here's how to think different:

1. Question Everything

>  Don't follow the herd. Challenge assumptions.
- Keep asking, "Why?" until you find the truth.
- Shake up the status quo before you get disrupted.

2. Forge your own path

> Ignore conventions and industry "rules".
- Forge new paths aligned with your vision.
- Create product categories that never existed.

3.  Never Stop Reinventing Yourself

> Keep evolving. No coasting on past wins.
- Disrupt your own products first.
- Initiate change yourself. Don't wait.

4. Pour Your Heart Into It

> Money is a side effect, not the goal.
- Create kick-ass products with passion.
- Prioritise quality over short-term gains.

5. Embrace the Crazy Ones

> Surround yourself with creative risk-takers.
- Encourage crazy ideas and bold thinking.
- Create an environment for radical ideas to thrive.

6. Sweat the Details

> Design beautifully simple products.
- Obsess over every detail. No cutting corners.
- Demand perfection. Prioritise user experience.

7. Stay Hungry and Foolish

> Never be satisfied with past accomplishments.
- Approach every day with a beginner's mindset.
- Stay hungry and foolish enough to create the future.

"Your time is limited, so don't waste it living someone else's life"
- Steve Jobs

 Which one of these rules do you follow?

---
If you enjoyed this content, you might like my newsletter:

‚è© Future Forward:

I have 10 free resources for you.

comments.commentText:
I really enjoyed reading this post.

Here's my takeaway:

I‚Äôve always believed that questioning everything brings clarity.

I remember challenging some project norms and discovering hidden opportunities no one else noticed.

That changed my approach to everything.

üü£ Question = Clarity.
üü£ Clarity = New Paths.
üü£ New Paths = Big Impact.

Challenge the norms, and you‚Äôll see fresh ideas emerge. 

:)
Atul Raghav great takeaway and love your approach!

These principles provide a roadmap for fostering radical innovation. Constantly reinventing yourself (principle 3) and obsessing over details (principle 6) are especially crucial for staying ahead in fast-changing industries. Encouraging bold, unconventional thinking (principle 5) also creates the foundation for breakthroughs.

posts.name:
Nuwpur Jain
Nuwpur Jain
posts.content:
My dadi died 7 days back BUT she lived an absolutely full life which shocks me even today

Here's what made her extraordinary:

1) The Family Matriarch: She nurtured an incredible legacy of 51 hearts - 6 children, 18 grandchildren, and 27 great-grandchildren. Each one carrying a piece of her boundless love.

2) The Eternal Explorer: At 80+, she had the curiosity of a 21-year-old, traveling from Singapore to Dubai, and finally to Ram Mandir - living life with more enthusiasm than people a quarter her age.

3) The Graceful Goodbye: Seven days ago, she left us exactly how she lived - peacefully, having fulfilled all her wishes, and without suffering. A perfect ending to a life lived perfectly.

Here's to you, Dadi - forever young, forever loved Ô∏è

comments.commentText: Nuwpur, your tribute to your grandmother beautifully captures the essence of a remarkable life well-lived. Her legacy of love and curiosity is truly inspiring and serves as a reminder of how to embrace life fully, regardless of age. Thank you for sharing such heartfelt memories.
Priyank Ahuja Living proof that the best things in life come without an expiry date

posts.name:
Sandeep Kochhar
Sandeep Kochhar
posts.content:
Read this on quora, 
A family of 4 manages in 55k per month in Bengaluru:) This person is saving 76% of his salary. Interestingly most families in India are unable to save more than 10% of their salaries. This figure is not dependent on how much you earn but on how much you spend which you can control.

This person could even earn 1 lakh a month still be laughing away to the bank because he still can save 45% of what he earns :)

What do you think?

comments.commentText: The author is living in a dreamland. Rent in Bangalore for a decent one bhk is around 25000. Even if you take the low cost vehicle and just comprehensive policy without addons will be minimum 4 to 5000. The car needs servicing every 6 months, minimum 8000 per servicing. 2nd child is toddler so needs immunisation of around 5000 a year plus needs to incorporate for medical expenses. In Bangalore , u need post tax income of minimum 1lac for breakeven for a respectful living for a family of 4.

posts.name:
Jon W. Lassiter
Jon W. Lassiter
posts.content:
Building greatness starts long before the results show.

It‚Äôs the late nights spent strategizing, the early mornings refining your vision, and the focus to tackle today‚Äôs challenges while preparing for tomorrow‚Äôs opportunities.

Every small step you take compounds over time, paving the way to something extraordinary. Keep going, you‚Äôre building greatness!

comments.commentText: All very true! It's like when you're in college and it feels like it will take forever for your career to start and for you to be successful. You just gotta keep moving forward! You'll get there
Niki I just had that exact conversation with my oldest son, a senior at UGA...stay the course!
I like this perspective! It's a collection of all the small changes that make for observable success. People don't often see all the work that goes into building something great.
The behind-the-scenes effort often goes unnoticed, but it's what builds the foundation for lasting success.

posts.name:
Janhvi Gaur
Janhvi Gaur
posts.content:
India Needs an Airline Brand Ô∏è

I was reading about the Indian aviation industry recently, and one thought struck me: India has airlines, but we don‚Äôt really have a true airline brand.

IndiGo? It‚Äôs convenient, reliable‚Äîbut does it stand for anything more?
Vistara? It had potential but wasn‚Äôt given enough time to build a legacy.
Akasa? It‚Äôs too new to shoulder that responsibility.

But then there‚Äôs Air India. With the Tata Group behind it, Air India is sitting on a golden opportunity. Yet, the question is: will they grab it?

Here‚Äôs the thing‚ÄîIndian aviation has been stuck in a loop. Every airline fights to win that one moment when travelers compare ticket prices on apps. Marketing is focused on discounts, flash sales, and price-first decisions.  But brands aren‚Äôt built on discounts.

Look at Emirates. They don‚Äôt sell cheaper tickets‚Äîthey sell an experience. You know you‚Äôre paying more, but you‚Äôre okay with it because of what the brand represents. That‚Äôs the kind of space Air India could occupy for Indian travelers.

Think about it:
1Ô∏è‚É£ The Tata Factor: The Tatas have the financial strength to play the long game. They‚Äôve already mastered Indian hospitality with Taj Hotels. (Imagine bringing that level of service to the skies.)

2Ô∏è‚É£ Evolving Travelers: We‚Äôve changed as consumers. People are willing to pay more for a better experience. It‚Äôs not just about reaching the destination anymore‚Äîit‚Äôs about how you get there.

It‚Äôs about creating a story that connects with people‚Äîone that makes them feel proud to choose Air India. It‚Äôs about more than transportation; it‚Äôs about aspiration.

If Air India can crack this, it won‚Äôt just be an airline‚Äîit‚Äôll be the Indian airline. The one we look at and say, ‚ÄúYes, that represents us.‚Äù

I really hope the Tatas see this moment for what it is‚Äîa chance to create something iconic.

Can Air India finally become the airline we‚Äôre proud of?

comments.commentText: You've presented a compelling vision for Air India, Janhvi. The potential for a strong airline brand that reflects India's identity and aspirations is indeed significant. It‚Äôs fascinating to think about how service quality and customer experience can redefine an airline's legacy, especially with the Tata Group's exemplary reputation in hospitality. This is a critical juncture for Indian aviation, and I hope the Tatas seize this opportunity to craft a brand that resonates deeply with travelers.

posts.name:
Mark Firth
Mark Firth
posts.content:
Oh dear, this happened:

In the last 24 hours

‚Ä¢ Somebody asked me if I was a woman who wanted to progress in my career in the DMS

The perfect way to build rapport

‚Ä¢ Another marketer put a series of unsolicited events in my calendar

Presumably, they scraped my email and are mass-inviting

Just what we want

I love him already

‚Ä¢ 3 event invites to 'get clients with linkedIn and AI' - same messages, different people

How do you do better?

I'm ALL in on LIVE!

I want people to experience my energy and problem-solving real time

People still buy from people

And if you have an AI version of you

They will be attracted to the AI and not you

You might get leads

But they won't vibe

And they for sure won't close

It's like catfishing on a dating site

comments.commentText: It's worse when you tell someone what they offer isn't relevant to you at all and the follow up telling you to reach back if you need that same irrelevant thing you just rejected. Imagine how good at listening these folks are in real life. Ugh

Lora Jackson we‚Äôve been through this cycle before with Chaz when automation apps first came on the market 

They burned out quick. The efficacy of ai volume is gonna burn out way quicker
Yea, the invites automatically showing up on my calendar is very invasive and NOT the way to talk to me! Do these people even consider what works and what is a total turn off ‚ÄçÔ∏è
Christine Trumbull, CPA, CFO yeah this is a new one for me, give it 8 weeks and google will shut it down
